s.text: We chose to administer the NPI-Q two days post-admission because a significant number of patients on these units are most likely to be discharged or transferred two days post-admission.
This suggests that the behavioral problems exhibited were of moderate severity, resulting in mild to moderate distress to staff.
The caregiver then ranks the severity of the behavior exhibited on a scale of 1 to 3, with 3 being the most severe.

Several studies have suggested that patient charts do not always adequately report the occurrence of behavioral problems in acute care settings, and only the most severe problems are likely to be documented [ 18 19 20 ] . We felt that the NPI-Q would provide a more objective and reliable assessment of the extent of behavioral problems in this population.
Additionally, the caregiver ranks their level of distress from each behavior, on a scale of 1 to 5, with 5 indicating the most severe level of distress.
Additionally, the caregiver ranks their level of distress from each behavior, on a scale of 1 to 5, with 5 indicating the most severe level of distress.
In particular, anxiety, depression, irritability, and agitation/aggression were the most commonly observed behaviors.

The ROC procedure examines every predictor variable and their associated cutpoints and identifies the variables with the optimal balance between sensitivity and specificity for identifying those particular patients with the specific outcome of interest (namely, presence of behavioral problems).
Figure 1presents the number of behaviors exhibited in each of the different behavioral domains assessed by the NPI-Q.
Additionally, they found that the dominant rationale for the use of restraints in this population was patients disrupting their own treatment, rather than prevention of falls.
Figure 1presents the number of behaviors exhibited in each of the different behavioral domains assessed by the NPI-Q.

Indeed, in our recent investigation of clinical staff on acute care units, staff self reported that such behavioral problems were often encountered and of significant burden [ 13 ] . Yet, to date, little is known about the prevalence of agitation and behavioral problems in older patients in acute care settings.
